paragraph: Known for its ancient ruins and fountains. There are several fountains and churches and tourists often throw coins into an iconic marble fountain (Trevi) as tradition.

Jiufen is a historic hillside town known for its alleys filled with lanterns, traditional teahouses, and street foods. Originally a gold mining town with history dating back to the Qing dynasty, it reflects Japanese influence in architecture and teahouse culture from periods of Japanese rule. The town overlooks misty mountains and the Pacific ocean.

paragraph: Museo Nacional del Prado is a historic art museum/cultural landmark opening in 1819. It is known for displaying pieces by European painters Goya, Velázquez (notably Las Meninas), El Greco, and more. Visitors are able to see exhibits form the main collection along with rotating temporary exhibitions every few months. Paintings, sculptures, and drawings include a wide variety of historical and religious symbolism across a variety of art styles across the centuries.

The museum is located in the state capital of Abia State. It is home to a lot of artifacts and weapons used to fight during the war. Located inside the museum is a bunker that hid a radio station that was used to communicate during the war which lasted for two years and half between 1967 and 1970.

description: Preheat the oven to 225°F and line a baking sheet with parchment, Beat the egg whites until soft peaks form, Gradually add the sugar and beat until stiff peaks form, Fold in the lemon juice, then vanilla, and finally cornstarch, until well blended, Pipe the meringue mixture into nests using a Wilton 1M Tip, Use the back of a spoon to indent the center, Bake for 1 hour and 15 minutes, and then turn off the oven and leave it in there another 30 minutes to dry, Cool – transfer with the parchment paper to wire racks, Make Whipped Cream: Beat the cold heavy whipping cream with the sugar until light, airy, and pipeable, White airy, cloud-like meringue, crispy on the outside and marshmallow-soft on the inside.

paragraph: The rodeo is an event that takes place every spring, bringing together the city in a classic southern state fair, with games, rides, and hallmarks of the south like mutton busting, bull riding, barrel racing, steer wrestling, and more. Classic fair foods are abundant, complemented by BBQ and food from south of the border, reflecting the city's own cultural diversity. Enjoy views of livestock, cowboys, and the city skyline from the top of the ferris wheel.

ingredient: kidney beans, ghee, cumin, cloves, black cardamom, cinnamon, onion, ginger, garlic, turmeric, chilli powder, coriander powder, cumin, tomato, chilli, salt, garam masala, dried fenugreek,  coriander
description: Soak kidney beans overnight. Pressure cook kidney beans for 5 whistles, In a pan, roast spices in ghee till the whole spices turn aromatic. To the pan, add chopped onion, ginger and garlic and sauté till the onions turn golden brown. Keeping the flame on low, add spice powders. Sauté till the spices turn aromatic. Further, add tomato and cook till the oil separates from the sides. Add boiled kidney beans, chili, salt and water to adjust the consistency. Cover and simmer for 15 minute or until the flavors are absorbed well. Garnish with dried fenugreek and coriander. Dish should have gravy and should taste tangy and mildly spicy. The dish should look reddish orange in color.

paragraph: Amabere Ga Nyina Mwiru is a history site with caves that have stalagmites and stalactites which are constantly dripping a white/milky liquid made of limestone and water. It is associated with a myth amongst the Batooro (the ethnic group in that region) that the stalactites and stalagmites are the breasts of Nyinamwiru, a 14th Century princess whose breasts were cut off and thrown into these caves when she refused to marry the man her father had chosen for her.

paragraph: A restored maze-like marketplace where sand-colored walls, carved wooden beams, and lanterns shade narrow alleys full of spice shops, perfumers, and tailors. In the evenings, families walk past outdoor shops sipping karak tea while the smell of grilled kebabs and cardamom hangs in the warm air. Stray cats sleep between stone benches, drummers sometimes lead small parades, and a dedicated falcon market sits just behind the main square, with a modern glass skyline and a curved seaside just a short walk away.

Every twelve years, millions of pilgrims gather at the banks of a sacred river where astrologers mark the most auspicious alignment of the Sun, Moon, and Jupiter. At dawn, devotees descend the ghats for a ritual bath believed to cleanse generations of karma. Temporary camps, chanting processions, saffron-robed ascetics, and towering entrance gates fill the city, transforming it into a vast spiritual township. The event rotates only among a few ancient river cities that Hindu tradition identifies as places touched by drops of divine nectar.

paragraph: Sri Venkateswara Temple, considered to be the most sacred places in Hinduism, sits atop one of the 7 peaks of Tirumala Hills, attracting thousands of devotees every day. Nearly 50,000 people visit every day and the entire place reverberates with one name - "Govinda".

Every spring, the foothills below the Zabarwan Range burst into color as rows of tulips bloom across a vast terraced garden overlooking the shimmering Dal Lake. Visitors walk through sweeping lanes of red, yellow, purple, and white flowers that stretch as far as the eye can see. The cool mountain breeze, the distant snow peaks, and the lake’s reflection make the festival feel almost surreal. The event transforms the valley into a vibrant celebration of spring, drawing travelers from across the world to witness Asia’s largest tulip garden at its most spectacular moment.

Nyungwe National park is a rainforest hundreds of species. It is home to several hidden waterfalls and families of baboons and chimpanzees. The air is cool, damp and heavy and it is famous for a canopy walk.

Azadi Tower, translated as Freedom Tower, renamed in 1979 after the country's revolution, is a famous landmark monument, originally called the Shah's Memorial Tower, made in 1971 under the final king.  It's also been called Gate of Cyrus and Imperial Gate.  It is 148 ft tall, made from marble, and celebrates the country's 6000 years of recorded history.

paragraph: The Salmon Days is an annual event that takes place early October. This celebrates the spawning season of the salmon as they return to their "home creek", the Issaquah Creek. paragraph: On the last Saturday morning of every month, almost all citizens participate in this mandatory national service, often involving activities like street cleaning, building schools, or repairing infrastructure. During this time, all non-essential business and traffic stops nationwide for several hours. This practice is a key factor in the country being internationally recognized for its cleanliness and civic participation.

paragraph: Every February, a huge crowd gathers before sunrise on this hill in a tiny town just to watch a groundhog get lifted in the air like some kind of furry weather forecaster. People are bundled up with hot coffee while a group of guys in old-school top hats announce whether the groundhog "saw its shadow" or not. The whole thing feels like its half festival and half joke, but everyone cheers anyway, and the town basically turns into a block party for a few hours.

Every year, the river floods the plains, requiring the king to move from his summer home to higher ground. This practical relocation is the Kuomboka ceremony, which literally means "to get out of water." The event is signaled by loud royal drumming echoing across the water. The King travels on a huge black-and-white boat called the Nalikwanda, which carries a large replica elephant. He is rowed by over a hundred paddlers wearing distinctive red berets.

paragraph: It is often called the "Silicon Valley of Hardware", a place where hardware hackers and engineers from all around the world to find obscure microchips, drone parts, or custom LEDs that are impossible to source elsewhere. Just forty years ago, the metropolis surrounding this market was a quiet fishing village, but standing here now among the dense skyscrapers and flashing neon signs, you can physically feel the rapid "speed" of development. While the humidity here is intense, the energy of innovation in this specific electronic commercial hub is even thicker.

paragraph: Navruz is an annual event that happens in early spring to celebrate a new revival season of the nature coming after winter. Mostly popular in central Asia, it is a symbol nature's new birth. People come to gather to prepare variety of traditional foods and often celebrate Navruz in their neighborhood of small communities. The history of this event dates back to far back into Persian history.

paragraph: Every year, huge herds of wild animals move together across wide, savannah grassland. The ground shakes, and dusty clouds fill the air as they run in a giant group to find new food and water. Baby animals are born and join the journey, and dangerous river crossings make the journey risky. Sometimes, hungry animals wait to catch those who slow down. During this journey, the herds move from one place to another and eventually return, following an ancient path across the land.

sentence: Esta Rota de aventura pelas áreas de conservação permite os turistas amantes da natureza desfrutarem das belas paisagens, rica fauna, histórias sobre os locais e interação com as comunidades residentes ao longo das 3 províncias abrangidas pela rota.

paragraph: Fushimi Inari Shrine sits at the base of a small mountain in southern part of the city. The moment you arrive, you're hit by a quiet buzz of people moving toward the same bright-orange path of torii gates. The shrine is famous for said gates, so many that they fora  long, winding tunnel that feels almost otherworldly, all amidst a forest of huge trees. Small fox statues, known as Inari's messengers, peek out from corners and mossy steps as the path gets steeper. By the time you reach the top, the city spreads out below you, a contrast to the dense gates and foresty hills behind you.

paragraph: Boca do Inferno is a tourist spot located in a beach coastal city. It is known for its seaside scenic views of a sea cave, waves, and the ocean. paragraph: Olorgesailie Prehistoric Site is known for its abundant Acheulean handaxe discoveries and evidence of early human social and cognitive evolution. Mary and Louis Leakey (who were British Archeologists) in the 1940s were involved in the excavation of the site. The site, found 70 km south of a capital city in East Africa along a road called Magadi Road, was later intensively studied by Glynn Isaac and a Smithsonian-led team, given the discovery.

paragraph: Trinity Church is a historic Episcopal church that serves as the burial grounds for various famous figures in the city (including Alexander Hamilton, several John Jacob Astors, and Edward Koch). The first church building was built in 1698, and was re-erected several times as the building was destroyed. The current iteration of the church was constructed in 1846 and was the tallest building in the country for 10 years. Columbia University and Trinity High School were founded on church grounds and remain respected educational institutions in the city despite no longer maintaining any legal connection to the church.

paragraph: Isolated from the mainland, this island boasts an array of endemisms. One of the famous icon is a kind of tree in the south-western part of the island, with dense leaflets and massive trunks, whchi looks like it's planted upside down.
Not far away from the city's airport, there is a village where everyday is Christmas! Meet Santa Claus in-person and send postcard from this jolly village.

Gede ruins is an abandoned city by the sea shore. It is surrounded by an indigenous forest with monkeys and butterflies. The coral stone walls depict a presence of a mosque, palace and houses, evidence of a 15th century swahili community.

The city is built around a deep natural bay and is dominated by a granite peak topped with a massive art-deco statue of Christ with outstretched arms. Its southern beaches form a famous crescent of white sand backed by steep hills, while the neighborhood of Lapa is known for its arched former aqueduct. The city hosted the 2016 Summer Olympics and has one of the world’s largest New Year’s beach gatherings every year. Its urban forest, located within city limits, is one of the largest in the world.

The Yungang Grottoes feel like stepping into a stone library of ancient devotion. As you walk along the rock face, the cool air from the caves carries a faint mineral scent, and sunlight spills across hundreds of thousands of carved Buddhas. In the dim light, the carved Buddhas seem to glow from within—faces smooth and contemplative, robes cascading in ripples that feel almost soft despite their stone form. Some statues tower above you with a quiet, commanding presence; others are tucked into cavities no bigger than a lantern flame, like whispered prayers captured in rock.

paragraph: Matilda Newport Day, celebrated on the 1st of every December, is a holiday that celebrates the heroic act of Matilday Newport, a folk hero who defended the settlement of Cape Mesurado. On December 1 1822 during the battle of Fort Hill, the Dei, Bassa, and Gola people attacked the settlement. This attack led to the death of many of the cannoneers. She light the fuse of one of the cannons using a hot coal from her pipe. This resulted in exploision and changed the course of the battle which was initially in favor of the attackers.

Gardens by the Bay is a national garden and premier horticultural attraction. It showcases a diverse collection of over 1.5 million plants from around the world, including species from cool, temperate climates to tropical forests and habitats. The garden features 18 massive, tree-shaped vertical gardens known as Supertrees, and aims to both educate and entertain visitors with its whimsical features.

paragraph: This landmark is a mesquite. It is several centuries old, and is on top of a flat sandy area. A single tree stands in a landscape that is otherwise almost entirely empty. There is no visibe water source, but the tree continues to survive.

The Durbar Squares are in a bowl-shaped basin in the Himalayan Mountains. These squares were the royal seat of different Malla kingdoms before the 18th century. The Kumari, the living embodiment of the Hindu Goddess Durga, would live in the Kumari Chouk, which was a three-story temple in the Durbar Square.
